Harring Figueiredo wrote:
> 
> 
> 
> Sorry if this question does not belong here.
> 
> I am trying to use the TestCaseClassLoader to load some of my classes (For a
> different project :P).
> 
> I got it to work with a rather strange behavior. I am sure it is more of a
> 'id 10 t' type of error :).
> 
> Here is what I have:
> 
>   C implements CI  
> 
> 
> I can load C correctly; however, it says that C is not an intance of CI.
> 
> If I use the default class loader, it indeed says it is an 'instanceof' CI.
> 
> Andy ideas ? 

The JVM identifies classes with the class loader that loads them; 
therefore, if L1 loads C and L2 loads CI, then you have a problem. It's 
better to refer to a class as <L, C> where L is the loader that loads 
class C.

So the JVM sees that <L1, C> implements <L1, CI>, but <L1, CI> is a 
different class object than <L2, CI>, so the JVM can't see that <L1, C> 
also implements <L2, CI>. The solution is clear: change your situation 
so that either:

  * L2 loads C, or
  * L1 loads CI

As for how to do that, that depends on your code. Can you change L1/L2 
so that one is a parent of the other? A class loader can see classes 
loaded by its parent, but not the reverse.

Good luck.
--
